text.p: The Turkish Foreign Ministry said on Thursday it was expelling Iran's consul to the eastern town of Erzurum, following his reported criticism of comments by a leading military official.

"It was announced today...that the Islamic Republic of Iran's Erzurum chief consul Saeede Zare has been declared a 'persona non grata' and he must leave Turkey within 48 hours," a foreign ministry statement said.
The announcement added to a diplomatic row between Tehran and Ankara, which protested to Iran earlier this month about the Iranian ambassador's comments at an anti-Israel rally.
The statement did not give a reason for Zare's expulsion.

Turkey's state-run Anatolian news agency said Zare had accused the deputy chief of the Turkish armed forces, Cevik Bir, of "irresponsibility" for his comments about Iran during a trip to the United States.
Bir had described Iran as a "terrorist" state, according to Turkish newspapers.
"Some pressure groups, sent General Bir to the U.S. and made him speak. With the same thought, those powers sent tanks onto the streets of Sincan," Anatolian quoted Zare as having said.

The Turkish Foreign Ministry protested to Tehran early in February after Iran's ambassador Mohammad Reza Bagheri spoke in favour of Islamic law at an anti-Israel rally in the Ankara district of Sincan.
Tanks toured Sincan several days after the protest in an apparent warning to Islamists from the secularist army.
Bagheri left Turkey last week, but a senior member of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's Islamist Welfare Party said his departure had nothing to do with the event.
Erbakan, Turkey's first Islamist prime minister, visited Iran soon after forming a coalition with conservatives eight months ago.
